The other members of the group will use a portion of this loan to plant corn, with the goal of improving living conditions for their families. The loan will be used to buy organic manure for cultivating corn. 

His dream is to generate more income so he can build his house and provide a better quality of life for his family.

loans.use: to buy organic manure for cultivating corn.

loans.name: Sandra Del Rosario

texts.es:
Sandra es una mujer de 23 años, es soltera, vive en la ciudad de Ica con sus padres y hermanos, ella es una persona muy amable, trabajadora y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tiene de trabajar para apoyar a su familia, Sandra  no ha podido estudiar la carrera profesional de Enfermería que deseaba, en sus ratos libres le gusta distraerse escuchando música y en algunas ocasiones cocina un riquísimo Ceviche para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Sandra trabaja en su pequeño negocio de venta de ropa tanto para damas y caballeros, adicionalmente también brinda servicios de comida, ella vende almuerzos a diversos clientes, Sandra trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por los buenos precios y por el trato amable que brinda a los demás.
Sandra se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindad podrá realizar la compra de mayor cantidad y variedad de prendas de vestir, de esta manera tendrá su negocio mejor abastecido y atenderá a mas clientes, así pues ella seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de tener su propio puesto de ventas en un centro comercial de su ciudad.
texts.en:
Sandra is a 23-year-old woman. She is single and lives in the city of Ica with her parents and siblings. She is a very cheerful, hardworking, and enthusiastic person who has a strong desire to overcome. 

Unfortunately, due to a lack of economic resources and the fact that she needs to work to support her family, Sandra has not been able to study for the professional career in Nursing that she hoped for. In her free time, she likes to entertain herself by listening to music; sometimes, she cooks a delicious Ceviche to share with her family.

Through her own initiative, and with a lot of effort and dedication, Sandra works in her own small business selling clothes for women and men. In addition, she offers food services; she sells snacks to various customers. 

Sandra works every day for approximately 10 hours, and she believes that it’s going well for her because of her good prices and the kind manner that she has toward others. 

Sandra is very grateful to the Kiva lenders, because thanks to the help they have offered, she will be able to keep her store better stocked and serve more customers. Therefore, she will continue working and making an effort to achieve her greatest dream of having her own sales stand in the city’s commercial center.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen emigrated to the U.S. from Peru with her two sons 15 years ago. Her sons studied medicine in Peru, but were unable to continue in the U.S. Thereafter, Carmen's family worked in several different industries to make ends meet, but created only insufficient income to get by.

To get back on their feet, Carmen and both of her sons started a landscaping business. Over the past seven years, they have built a steady clientele and have used punctuality and superior service to separate themselves from their competition. When Hurricane Sandy hit, Carmen's house and landscaping equipment were destroyed. In order to continue business during the landscaping season this year, Carmen used her assets to buy one new mower and rent another. With a loan of $5,350, Carmen can buy an additional mower and revive her business. Carmen anticipates her new capital will allow her to expand her clientele and give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase a new mower for her landscaping business and recover from Hurricane Sandy.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa emigrated to the U.S. from Honduras in 1998.  Before starting her own business, Rosa worked as an employee in another restaurant for many years. Rosa decided two years ago that she no longer wanted to be an employee and opened “Mi Rosita Restaurant.”

“Mi Rosita Restaurant” serves specifically Honduran food in a predominantly Hispanic area, which separates it from other local restaurants. 

With the help of a $3,150 loan, Rosa can buy new chairs and tables to improve the look of her restaurant and attract more customers. She can also buy an icemaker that would save her the time and capital she spends on buying ice daily.

Rosa hopes to grow her restaurant business and eventually open a new restaurant in order to better support her four sons.

loans.use: To buy new tables, chairs, and an icemaker for her restaurant.

loans.name: Jose De La

texts.en:
Jose moved to the U.S. from Santo Domingo less than a year and a half ago. In Santo Domingo, Jose conducted a remodeling business. Jose has continued with the same line of work since moving to the U.S. Recreating that business in the U.S. was difficult because Jose had to redevelop his client base. For some time, Jose only reached out to family and friends. His great quality work then sent many referrals his way. 

Currently, Jose works the night shift at another job and works at his business part time. Ideally, Jose would like to grow his business enough to do remodeling full time and maybe even bring on other full-time employees. 

The loan of $2,150 will help Jose buy materials for his work and will help him get more jobs and provide better quality service to his clients. Eventually, he hopes this business will grow enough for him to work on it full time and leave his night job. Overall, he thinks success in this business could give his family a brighter future.

loans.use: To buy materials for his remodeling business and serve more clients.

loans.name: Damon

texts.en:
Damon is no stranger to the difficulties of homeownership, especially after the economic downturn of 2008. After having to deal with credit challenges and foreclosures the hard way, Damon decided to become a beacon of hope for other prospective homeowners in the community.

As a real estate consultant, Damon helps clients establish a rental background, find lending and eventually find the property right for them. The loan of $3,775 will help Damon increase his marketing and infrastructure, which will help him reach more clients. His future plans include making consulting education available through online classes.

loans.use: To market his business and help more people become homeowners.

loans.name: Gladis

texts.en:
Gladis is a Mexican immigrant who arrived in the U.S.16 years ago. She worked several jobs in her first few years here, but found a long-term career in hairdressing.

Gladis’ husband owns a restaurant called Las Cazuelas. Gladis divides her time between the restaurant and working at the William Anthony hair salon. As Gladis has the spirit of a hairdresser, she prefers to work at William Anthony full time. Her entrepreneurial drive, which she also cultivated at an Intersect Fund Class in 2009, has led her to consider buying the salon herself. With a loan of $5,335, Gladis can buy the salon and run her own business.

Gladis aspires to grow her business eventually into a complete spa that provides facials, nail care, and many other services.

loans.use: To buy a hair salon and start working toward her own goals.

loans.name: Ronald

texts.en:
Ron doesn’t run your ordinary collections agency. Instead of harassing clients about their collections, he builds relationships with them – and then helps them build their credit.

Ron looks at collections as a way to give back to the community and the refuel the local economy. Ron regularly helps disadvantaged groups to build their credit. In fact, Cash-Flow Credit Counseling did community service at a local women’s shelter helping the women understand and build their credit scores.

Ron visits his customers personally and sends them thank-you notes when payments are made. He strongly believes in this model of credit building because it helps people get mortgages and loans, which spurs spending. He aspires to replicate this model around the country to change the way collections are done everywhere. 

The loan of $4,285 will help Ron pay for a phone, equipment, and marketing, which will bring in more customers, increase revenue, and eventually help him give more back to the community.

Check out Cash-Flow Credit Counseling & Collections below.
http://cf.mandocentrik.info/

video.title: Kiva Borrower Ronald from United States

loans.use: To develop his communications infrastructure and give more back to the community.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny emigrated to the U.S. from Peru in 2003. She has worked for Avon for many years, initially helping someone else who was selling Avon products. Seven months ago, Jenny started selling her own products in her whole new boutique!

Jenny is very excited to be selling accessories, gifts, and Avon products in her own storefront! Jenny has dedicated much effort to opening her own boutique. She hopes to expand, rent more space, and sell more inventory soon.

The loan will help Jenny buy more holiday inventory, improve her presentation and develop her clientele. She hopes that this expansion in her business will allow her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy new holiday inventory for her boutique.

loans.name: Natividad

texts.en:
Natividad came to the U.S. from Peru in 2006. For his first 10 months here, Natividad fixed electronics and machines. That work did not produce enough money to support himself and his family, so he decided to start a business in signs and glassmaking, an area he already had experience in from Peru.

Natividad provides superior quality and uniqueness in his work. He is flexible and provides impeccable customer service. 

The loan of $3,250 will help Natividad buy tools and marketing materials that will expand his customer base and help him do more jobs. Eventually, Natividad aspires to become the regional leader in his industry.

loans.use: To buy equipment for his business and reach out to new clients

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna emigrated to the U.S. from Peru nearly 15 years ago. With two daughters and a son to support, Myrna had to work full time and cater from her house on the weekends to make ends meet. When her son unfortunately fell ill, Myrna had to leave the country for his treatment. During that time period, she lost her house and her job.

Myrna has made a remarkable recovery since then and opened her own restaurant. The seasoned caterer is now proving her expertise at her storefront. Myrna hopes that her restaurant will be successful and sustain her family. She aspires to one day expand to having more restaurants.

Myrna needs a loan to recover from the damage Hurricane Sandy had on her restaurant. The loan of $1,320 will help her buy new equipment and restore the restaurant itself. She hopes that with the renewal, her restaurant will thrive and she will finally be able to support her family comfortably.

loans.use: To recover from the toll Hurricane Sandy took on her restaurant.

loans.name: Ankadignongne Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe ANKADIGNONGNE, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Barouéli, préfecture de Ségou ; Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de tubercules, de savon, d’articles divers et de céréales.                                                 .                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe sont à leurs onze prêts solidaires.                                                                         
La cliente FANTA qui est assise en deuxième position a partir de la gauche, compte acheter 800 kilos d’arachide avec les grossistes du village et environnants. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place au Barouéli au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The Ankadignongne group of women are all married, and average 41 years of age with two children. All live in traditional extended families in the city of Barouéli, municipality of Segou, in the Segou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They became acquainted through kinship and neighborhood ties, and friendship. They sell vegetable tubers, soap, sundries and grain cereals. The women in the group are on their eleventh group loan.

Fanta is the member sitting second from the left. She plans to buy 800 pounds of groundnuts from wholesalers in the village and the surrounding area. She conducts her daily sales in Barouéli for cash and credit to a clientele composed of men and women.

She plans to make average monthly profits of 25,000 FCFA that will be used to contribute towards social ceremonies. The rest will be reinvested in her trading business.

loans.use: buy groundnuts

loans.name: Yenifer

texts.en:
Yenifer is passionate about working with children. For six years, Yenifer volunteered to babysit kids. Through her experiences, she saw the great need for daycares in her community.

Now, Yenifer is starting her own “Mami’s Daycare.” She says, “I am still in the start-up phase of my business, but the loan has helped me to pay for state license, permits, and construction that are required for my daycare business.”

With the help of this loan, Yenifer will be able to finish the construction of “Mami’s Daycare” and meet the needs of mothers and fathers in the community that work late nights or are attending school. She loves her community and aspires to give back with flexible hours and late hours of operation for these parents.  The above photo features Yenifer with her baby, a relationship in her life that inspires her to work with children.

loans.use: To proceed with the construction of her daycare and acquire the state licenses that are required to provide daycare services to the community.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria was born and raised in the Dominican Republic where she opened her first beauty salon. In 2002, Maria emigrated to the U.S. Here in America, Maria worked in other salons for over 10 years. She opened her own parlor four months ago. From the parlor, she also sends money internationally for customers. Maria has high aspirations for her business. She hopes to expand and eventually open more salons. 

This loan will allow Maria to create a web presence, buy more inventory, and most importantly, build her credit so she will have access to more capital in the future. Maria is confident that her personal relationship with her customer base and her unbeatable prices will lead her new venture to thrive!

loans.use: To buy inventory and advertise her beauty salon.

loans.name: Hector

texts.en:
Hector comes from Honduras. Back in his own country, Hector used to work in the car business. After moving to the U.S. eight years ago, he started working in construction. He then had an accident, which left him unable to continue construction work. It was then that Hector reverted back to his passion, and started a business in which he sells, rents, and repairs cars.

This loan will allow Hector to buy the spare parts he needs to repair 7 of 30 cars in his shop so that he can sell and rent them out to the community. The repairing of these cars will allow him to generate more business and lead him to more success. Hector has great entrepreneurial drive and is very thankful for this opportunity to do what he loves!

loans.use: to buy spare parts to repair seven cars

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a Peruvian immigrant who has been in the U.S. for about 10 years. Elizabeth was working as a medical representative when she was first introduced to Avon. Being the fashion-savvy woman she is, Elizabeth was attracted to the business model and started selling Avon part time.

Before she knew it, Elizabeth’s clientele grew exponentially! Capitalizing on her entrepreneurial drive, Elizabeth recently opened her own boutique where she sells Avon, jewelry, and cell phone services. Elizabeth is with her husband, Samuel, in the photo of their boutique above. Elizabeth has learned the ins-and-outs of Avon and has become an expert in selling beauty products.

Now Elizabeth wants to take advantage of the opportunity to be her own boss and a successful entrepreneur. This loan will allow Elizabeth to market her business in more magazines and at more events, and realize her potential as a businesswoman.

loans.use: to advertise her boutique.

loans.name: Diego

texts.en:
Diego is an Ecuadorian immigrant who moved to the U.S. in 2010. Not being able to find a job pushed him to start his own business, in which he exports products from the U.S. to Ecuador. He identified that there was a large Ecuadorian population on the East coast and therefore, there was a demand for the exportation of products that people wanted to send back home. 

Diego’s goals are to expand his business into other states where the Ecuadorian population is growing. The loan of $2,150 will allow Diego to purchase a van and have working capital for his business. With both of these, he hopes to offer new product lines in Ecuador and the U.S.

loans.use: to purchase a van and transport more exports.

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo was born in Ecuador. At the age of 18, he started a business selling products to people in his town and nearby cities. Thirteen years ago, he decided to explore the United States and learn about new technology. When he arrived in the U.S., he worked a low-wage job for about four months. He then started his own business with the savings he had accumulated over many years. Leonardo distributes cosmetic products all over the U.S.  

Leonardo's goals are to expand his product line to new and previous customers. This loan will help Leonardo purchase a vehicle, advertise his business, and visit more stores in order to increase his sales.

loans.use: to purchase a new vehicle, pay for advertising and pay for travel to new accounts

loans.name: James

texts.en:
When Jimmy was only 16 years old, his mom gave him $800 worth of savings. Jimmy put it into installing his first sound and light system in his own basement. When people started noticing, they called him to set up their parties too. It was in this way that Jimmy's business started. Now, 20 years later, Jimmy is a professional DJ and sound/light installer. Jimmy sets up any stage, from basements to banquet halls. He has contracts with several important venues in the area. 

Jimmy is proud of what he does. Being a DJ and installing sound and light systems have been his passion for over half his life. With this loan of $5,250, he can purchase brand new lighting equipment, land his next big contract, and truly turn his basement business into a success.

loans.use: To purchase the lighting equipment that will allow him to land his next big contract.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is a hard working woman. She has spent years working full time at a laundromat, and has even done catering from home on the weekends just to be able to pay the mortgage. Even though things have been tough for her, Juliana has always believed she could start a venture of her own and become her own boss.

And Juliana is doing just that. Recently, she saw an opportunity in a Mexican restaurant that was being shut down. She took advantage of the moment and bought the place, which she has transformed into a restaurant for Peruvian cuisine. Juliana is set up for a grand opening very soon. She is confident in her venture because she already has a loyal client base from her home catering business.

Juliana needs basic working capital as she prepares for the opening. The money from this loan will be used for food, inventory, and other start-up costs that she needs to cover for her enterprise to be successful.

loans.use: to buy the inventory and food needed for her upcoming restaurant opening.

loans.name: Julio

texts.en:
Julio was born and raised in El Salvador. He used to work in the operations department of a bank. Unfortunately, the banking system became unstable, and he decided to leave his country and come to the United States with his daughter. He first worked at a minimum wage job, but was unable to provide his family with the basic necessities. He was then introduced to Herbalife, where he developed his salesmanship skills. Three years ago, he decided to open up his own Herbalife Club, which has fortunately been very successful. Since then, demand for his products has been growing. 

Julio’s goals are to expand his product line to new countries and to open Herbalife Clubs in more cities. The loan of $6,925 will allow Julio to renovate his store, purchase more inventory, and do more marketing.

loans.use: to renovate his store, purchase more inventory, and do more marketing.

loans.name: Ramon

texts.en:
Ramon has been in the car business for a long time. He has been the go-to mechanic in his community for years. Since he moved to the U.S. from the Dominican Republic, he has run a successful auto repair shop.

Recently, Ramon has decided to branch out to the trucking and transportation businesses. He picks up containers from ports and vice versa. In order to complete this expansion, Ramon needs a loan to buy a new truck. Because he is very well known and has faithful clients, he is sure that this expansion will happen successfully.

loans.use: To purchase a truck to expand his transportation business.

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Nicolas emigrated to the U.S. in 1999. For three years, he worked for a distributor that was importing and exporting Mexican food products. He learned the business model and decided to start his own business. He has now had own his food distribution business for over 12 years. As the price of organic food has gone slightly down, and demand for organic food has gone up, Nicolas felt the need to increase the number of his organic products. He wants to do this to be both socially responsible and responsive to his customers’ needs.  

This loan will allow Nicolas to expand his new organic food product line and be one of leading organic distributors in New Jersey.

loans.use: to buy more organic products to sell

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph repairs shoes the traditional way: he sews them by hand. He is widely recognized for being one of the last cobblers in his area. Some even say he’s the best shoemaker in town! Anyone who has been to Joseph’s store knows that he works six days a week and eleven hours a day, without ever taking a day off. 

Joseph, originally from Africa, received his training in shoe repair in Germany. After moving to the U.S., he opened his own shoe store, which he has now had for over 20 years. Joseph has kept alive what many would call a lost art. In order to sustain his business, Joseph has requested a loan. This loan will allow him to buy more inventory and increase his marketing. Joseph knows his hard work and commitment to his craft will continue to pay off!

loans.use: To increase marketing and inventory for his shoe business.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean has always been a caretaker by nature. By being a teacher and daycare employee for many years, Jean has become a mother, in her own right, to every child she cares for and educates. She is well respected in her community for this very reason. Jean knows her community is in need of a daycare with extended hours for hard-working parents. 

Once this need was identified, Jean knew she wanted to be the one to create the solution. The only thing stopping her from opening her own childcare center was the lack of access to capital. It is for exactly this reason that Jean requested a loan. With this loan, Jean can buy furniture for her daycare. With the presence of her daycare, more children will have caretakers when their parents are working, and will be educated by a sharp woman at the same time. In the future, she hopes to expand and employ more caretakers just as passionate as she is.

loans.use: to purchase furniture for her daycare center.

loans.name: Ulda

texts.en:
Ulda and her family have been in the bakery business a long time. When her dad first came to the U.S., he was a driver for several bread distributors. He then became an independent driver and opened his own bread distribution business 20 years ago. When Ulda and her mom came to the U.S. from Ecuador, they joined in and made it a family business.

Ulda and her family are now looking to expand their enterprise and become bread manufacturers themselves. They already have the customer base from years of work in the industry and they plan to distribute to supermarkets, delis, and restaurants with whom they already have relationships. Her family is very hard working and successful. Their origins in Ecuador were humble: Ulda’s father had to move from city to city to keep food on the table. Still, Ulda believes her family can and will be well off. In order to become manufacturers, the family will need to buy equipment and a cold room. This loan will allow Ulda’s family to do just that and keep their business thriving.

loans.use: to buy equipment needed to become a bread manufacturer.

loans.name: Kuku

texts.en:
Kuku’s business, Kristal Cargo, offers international cargo shipment services for consumers, primarily to Nigeria. Kuku collects boxes from customers at his home and aggregates them together into 3-5 shipments per month that are sent via air to Lagos, Nigeria. Kuku’s customers are primarily Nigerian immigrants from all over New Jersey who are sending packages to their home country. So far, Kuku has been operating his business from his living room. He has even removed his dining table in order to support it.

Kuku needs this loan of $10,000 to buy a plot of land on which he can build a warehouse to sustain his business. This will increase Kuku’s capacity and allow him to take even larger shipments in the future. Right now, Kuku has his tractor parked outside of his home in a residential area. In order to respect zoning laws and not be shut down, Kuku needs to find another place for it soon. A plot of land will provide him a space within which to park it. Kuku hopes to grow his business enough within the next three years to quit his installation work. He is happy that his business helps Nigerian immigrants send shipments back home and maintain ties with their home country.

loans.use: to purchase a plot of land on which he can build a warehouse

loans.name: Mesaid

texts.en:
Mesaid has a business operating a fruit and vegetable stall. She sells from home to her neighbors and she dreams of establishing a mini green grocer in the future.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase four sacks of fruit and three sacks of vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support and she is thankful and grateful for the support.

loans.use: to purchase four sacks of fruit and three sacks of vegetables for resale

loans.name: Concordia

texts.en: Concordia is a 42-year-old married woman who operates a sari-sari (variety) store in the town of Talibon, Bohol.  She has five children. She sells goods including sugar, noodles, biscuits and soft drinks. She started her business 10 years ago. Concordia requested a loan of 3,000 PHP to buy stock such as seasoning, condiments and soft drinks. She hopes to have enough savings so she can live comfortably. In the future, Concordia plans to make her store bigger so she can continue in a bigger way with a better profit.

loans.use: to buy stock such as seasoning, condiments and soft drinks

loans.name: Mon

texts.en:
Living in a thatched roof house in a rural village of the Dambae district of Kampong Cham province, Mon is 39 years of age and married. He and his wife have three children, two of whom are still in school. Mon and his wife earn a living through farming rice and planting cassava and they have been in this business for almost twenty years. With his current business, he is able to earn approximately 45,000 KHR per day to support his family. 
This is the first loan for Mon with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. He is requesting a loan with VisionFund of 1,500,000 KHR to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for his farmland. He hopes to improve his crop yields and to sell the rice for a good price so as to improve his lifestyle.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for his farmland

loans.name: Sat

texts.en: Sat, 24, lives in a rural area of the Tbaung Khmum district of Kampong Cham province and she is married with two children. The family’s main sources of income are from planting cassava and farming rice in the local village. She has been in this business for several years. She can earn about 40,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. Sat has been with VisionFund for two cycles and has completely repaid the loans, which has helped to relieve the family's burden and to improve their livelihood. To support her business, she is requesting a loan with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund, of 2,600,000 KHR. She will use this loan to buy fertilizers for her farmland and will also use a portion of it to spend on labor and land plowing. With this loan, she hopes to make more income so as to make a better living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Rahila

texts.en:
Rahila is a 57-year-old widowed woman with 3 children. She sells different kind of goods as flour, beverages, macaroni, butter, and candies. She has 10 years of experience and has a deep knowledge of the market and demand of clients.

Food product she sells are very popular among people and in high demand. Her monthly profit from selling foods is 120 AZN. Her son helps to purchase products and bring them to the shop. This is the sole financial income in her family. She is a very successful entrepreneur because of the good location, in the central bazaar of her home city.

Now she needs 1900 AZN, an amount to expand her business in the future. She has a good credit history. This is a her 3rd loan.

loans.use: to buy more grocery products for her store

loans.name: Xirda

texts.en:
Xirda is 50 years old and not married. She lives with her parents in her own city. She is selling food products such as macaroni, rice, candies, cookies, sugar and beverages. Her brother is helping her in this business. This is only source of income to their family, and from this business her monthly profit is  about 150 AZN. She has 8 years of experience in this field. 

People in her town are regular customers who purchase food products and other available items at the store. She is a very successful entrepreneur because of her good location in the bazaar of her home city.

Xirda wants to expand her business and to buy more products. For this purpose she applied for 2,000 AZN. She has a good client history and this will be her 2nd loan.

loans.use: to buy more products.

loans.name: Mendbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Mendbaatar, age 42, lives with his wife and two sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been working as a salesman at a private business entity, which requires him to use his own automobile to drive around the city to sell the products. His wife has been selling clothes at a trade center by renting a stall since 2010. His elder son works at a television station as a spokesman. 

Mendbaatar is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 MNT to purchase various types of clothes in order to support his wife's business. In this way, they can run the business without worrying about inventory shortage and they can satisfy the needs of customers. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase various types of clothes in order to sell.

loans.name: Azar

texts.en:
Azar  is 47 years old, married and the father of two children. He has his own business selling food products.  Azar’s son is also helping him in this business, because it is only finance income to their family.  

Azar sells food products like macaroni, rice, candies, cookies, sugar and beverages in his shop. He has 15 years of experience in this field, and this allows him to consider himself as a knowledgeable and skilled person. His true profession is accounting, which helps him to run this business effectively by knowing every little expense.

The food products he sells are very popular among people and are in high demand. His monthly profit from selling foods is 100 AZN. He is a very successful entrepreneur because of a good location, in the central bazaar of his home city.

Azar has applied for 2000 AZN, which he will use to purchase and diversify additional food stuff.

Azar would like to increase his sales and invest additional capital.

loans.use: to expand his business by buying more food products.

loans.name: Hamida

texts.ru: Хамида образованная женщина, проживающая в районе Рудаки. Ей 39 лет. Она замужем и у нее трое детей. Хамида имеет высшее образование. Она работает учительницей в средней школе. Так как ее зарплата очень маленькая и не хватает на нужды семьи, Хамида решила заняться собственным бизнесом. Жаркое лето это сезон торговли арбуза и дыни. Поэтому Хамида проанализировав решила заняться торговлей в этой сфере. Она уже приобрела торговую точку на рынке района. К тому же у нее имеется стартовый капитал в размере 4000 сомони, высланные мужем, который находится на заработках в России. Хамида запрашивает кредит. Она на сумму кредита и сбережения хочет закупить арбузы и дыни, и начать торговлю. Занявшись этим прибыльным бизнесом, Хамида сможет улучшить финансовое положение семьи.
texts.en: Hamida is an educated woman who lives in Rudaki. She is 39 years old, married and has three children. Hamida has a college degree and works as a teacher at the local school. Since her salary is too small toprovide for her family, Hamida has decided to start her own business. The hot summer is the season for selling watermelons and cantaloupes. Hamida analyzed the market and decided to sell these fruits. She has already purchased a market stall and she has a starting capital of 4000 somoni, which were sent by her husband, a migrant worker in Russia. Hamida will use this loan along with her savings to purchase watermelons and cantaloupes and start selling them. This lucrative business will help Hamida improve the financial situation of her family.

loans.use: to purchase watermelon and cantaloupes and start her own business

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is 41 years old and lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has seven children, all of whom currently attend school. For the past seven years, Stephen has been working hard to manage his small business, which sells glass. 

To help expand his business, Stephen has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more glass to sell, and will help Stephen to generate greater profits and pay his children's school fees. Stephen hopes that in the future he will be able to provide better quality building glass in town. 

Stephen is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Stephen who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more building glass to sell

loans.name: Tamaz

texts.en:
Tamaz is 45 years old and lives with his wife and a son in Kobuleti, littoral town of Georgia. His wife, Maya, stays home taking care of her child. His son, Luka, is ten years old and studies at a local primary school. 

Tamaz has purchased a mini-bus and now has small-scale trading business. He buys different kinds of products, such as dishes and clothing, at wholesale prices and sells them in the villages near Kobuleti with a price mark up. Tamaz uses his mini-bus for product transportation and is the only income provider in the family. His profit is not enough to cover everyday expenses. 

In order to improve his family’s finances, Tamaz is requesting a loan of $1300 to purchase spare parts and to cover repair fees of his mini-bus to start his transportation service business and connect the passengers to neighboring towns. He will also install seats in his mini-bus to offer comfortable journey to his clients. 

Tamaz’s loan request was approved in the frames of new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

In the future Tamaz would like to purchase new household items and furniture for improving the lifestyle of the family.

loans.use: to cover repair fees of his mini-bus for starting a transportation service business.

loans.name: Murad

texts.en: Murad began working as a car repairman when he was 17 years old. He repairs and paints completely damaged cars. His work is his only source of income. He is a very capable young man, his dream is to expand and have a better opportunity to help his parents and sisters. Today Murad's aim is to buy a cheap battered car, restore and re-sell it at a higher price. Money from the sale will be used to invest in the expansion of his auto shop and the purchase of new equipment for its operation.

loans.use: to buy on the cheap the crumpled car, build it again, restore and re-sell it.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a divorced woman who has been blessed with two children. She lives in a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food and rental bills.

She operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and villagers. Her greatest challenge is the high cost of transportation. With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase charcoal for resale. She dreams of expanding into a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Mandzaanos Group

texts.en:
The group is made up of six members and all are females. They live in the same neighborhood and are into the trading of footwear, cooking utensils, underwear, cutlery sets and fish.

Comfort, who sells products such as footwear and sachet water (water bagged in small plastic bags), is very excited to receive her sixth loan from ID-Ghana, after having repaid her previous loans and thus taken a step towards expanding her business. With this loan, she is planning to use GHS 1200 to purchase a bag of footwear and forty bags of sachet water.

Comfort says that her most important challenge and goal is to set up a store where she can sell all of her items instead of going outside and walking in her communities and others nearby. She enjoys being at home with her long-term husband and three children. She is planning to reinvest her profits in her business and save for her future plans and challenges.

The group needs a total amount of GHS 6700 to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase a bag of footwear and forty bags of sachet water and sell to customers.

loans.name: Soule

texts.fr:
Monsieur Soule est né en 1984, célibataire et sans enfants il vit dans une famille traditionnelle avec ses parents à Konobougou, cercle de Barouéli, Région de Ségou République du Mali. 
Il est installé à son compte il y’à  peu près deux ans, et il décide d’entrer en collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso pour mieux organiser son activité. Il est à son  premier prêt, qu’il compte utiliser pour achète  4 chèvres et 3 moutons et les revend aux bouchers et  commerçants de bétails. Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000 FCFA. 
Monsieur Soule  ambitionne d’agrandir son activité grâce à la collaboration que Soro.
texts.en:
Mr. Soule was born in 1984. He is single and does not have any children and lives in a traditional family with his parents in Konobougou, which is in the Barouéli circle in the Segou region of the Republic of Mali.
He started his business about two years ago and decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso in order to organise his business better. This is his first loan and he plans to use it to buy four goats and three sheep for resale to butchers and livestock dealers. He hopes to make an average monthly profit of 40.000 FCFA.
Mr. Soule hopes to enlarge his business thanks to his collaboration with Soro.

loans.use: To buy small ruminants.

loans.name: Tonia

texts.en:
Please meet 40-year-old Tonia from St. Paul, Liberia. St. Paul is home to the oldest market in Liberia and is known for their fish, due to its location by the sea.  St. Paul is a suburb located just outside Monrovia, past the Free port. It is one of the poorer areas and you will often find its residents living in sub-standard housing. 

She completed 12 grades and is single. She has four children between the ages of 25 and 19. They are in school and living on their own. Tonia owned a shop where she has been selling charcoal for the past 5 years in her community.  She will use the loan proceeds to purchase more charcoal for her business.
  
On average, she works 8hours at her business.  She started her business with money from her mother. She transports her merchandise by pickup.  She cites her small income as her biggest challenge.  Her favorite part of her business is making a profit.  In the future, she would like to build a house.  
She thanks you in advance for your support!

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi, sont de femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 48 ans, 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Klakouma, commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de vanne.                                                                 
Les femmes du groupe sont à leur seizième prêt solidaire. 
La cliente Fatoumata,  1 ère debout à droite fait le commerce de haricot préparé  pendant la nuit et le matin et celui de vannes et de la petite restauration la nuit.
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 2 sacs de haricots, 1 bidon d’huile alimentaire, 1 colis de condiments et 50 vannes, sur place
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 18 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour ses besoins de la famille et une partie est réinvestie dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group are married women who are on average 48 years old with five children. They all live in extended traditional families in Klakouma, in Massigui commune, Dioïla prefecture that is in the Koulikoro region (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali)
They came to know each other through friends and through living in the same neighbourhood. They sell basketwork.
This is the sixteenth solidarity loan for the women of the group.
Fatoumata who is the first standing on the right, sells beans prepared during the night and the morning and sells basketwork and snacks at night.
She plans to use her loan to buy locally two sacks of beans, one can of comestible oil, one bag of condiments and 50 canes.
She expects to make an average monthly profit of 18 000FCFA which she will use for her family's needs and part of it will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: to buy various articles.

loans.name: Sidlawende Ii Group

texts.fr:
Mme LAMOUSSA est la responsable du groupe SIDLAWENDE II. Marié, elle est mère de 04enfants. Le plus âgé a 14ans et le moins âgé a 04ans. 02 vont à l’école. 
Mme vend du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois depuis 06ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans les provinces environnantes. Ses clients sont les femmes.
Elle veut s’acheter une rangée de bois et un sac de charbon de bois.
Mme veut épargner ses bénéfices pour son activité. Elle ambitionne étendre les limites de son activité et scolariser ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs Lamoussa is the leader of the Sidlawende II group. She is married with four children. The oldest is 14 and the youngest is four. Two of them go to school.
Mrs Lamoussa has been selling firewood and charcoal for six years. She buys her stock in neighbouring regions. Her customers are women.
She wants to buy a rack of wood and a sack of charcoal.
Mrs Lamoussa   wants to save the profits for her business. Her ambition is to enlarge her business and send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy a rack of wood and a bag of charcoal.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is single and has two children who attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

She has operated a firewood selling business for the past three years. She sells from home to her neighbors; she faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of incorporating charcoal into her existing business in the near future.

With the loan she is requesting, she plans to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Felix

texts.es: Gracias al crédito obtenido por Kiva durante la cosecha pasada Felix pudo alcanzar su meta de producir 10 toneladas de café y además utilizó parte del dinero para abonar sus fincar y hacer labores de limpieza. Para este año Felix necesita otro crédito pues debe realizar otras labores en su finca y también fertilizará. Dentro de 3 años Felix tiene planeado estar cosechando un total de 15 toneladas de café.
texts.en:
Thanks to the Kiva loan Felix received during the last harvest, he was able to reach his goal of producing 10 tons of coffee.  He also used part of the loan to fertilize his plantation and clear weeds from the fields.

This year Felix needs another loan to carry out other tasks on the farm including fertilzation.  In a three-year period Felix plans to harvest a total 15 tons of coffee.

loans.use: to buy manure and to clear weeds from the fields.

loans.name: Djiguiseme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiseme, composé exclusivement de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 40 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier  de Guégnaka dans la ville de Fana, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce  de condiment d’habillements et d’articles divers.                                                                                                                          
Les femmes du groupe sont à leur douzième prêt.                                                                                                                                                                                  
La cliente Maïmouna, première personne à partir de la droite dans le rang des assises, compte acheter de l’oignon des poissons et de la patate à Niono chez les grossistes pour ensuite venir vendre à Fana Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice de 25000 FCFA par cycle.
texts.en:
The Djiguiseme group is exclusively made up of married women who on average are 40 years old with five children. They all live in extended traditional families in the Guégnaka quarter of Fana, Dioïla prefecture in the Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali)
They met through friends and living in the same neighbourhood. They sell condiments, clothes and various articles.
This is their 12th loan.
Maïmouna who is the first on the right sitting down, plans to buy onions, fish and potatoes from Niono the wholesaler to sell in Fana. She hopes to make a profit of 25000 FCFA for each rotation.

loans.use: to buy food products.

loans.name: Marisol

texts.es:
Marisol se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, como colonias, perfumes, ropa y otros. Todo su trabajo lo realiza en su casa o por las calles de la ciudad y inició en este trabajo hace 06 años, con el tiempo fue aprendiendo y capacitándose en técnicas de ventas. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que puede tener tiempo para poder hacer todas las actividades que desee, además de brindarle también atención a su hija, le está yendo muy bien ya que tiene ingresos que le permiten proyectarse algunos planes a futuro, pero lo que desea por ahora es seguir creciendo y aumentar la variedad de productos a ofrecer para que sus ganancias se multipliquen. Este es el segundo préstamo con Kiva y está muy contenta de saber que le brindan un apoyo financiero ya que eso le genera seguridad para avanzar con su trabajo, además se compromete a cumplir con el pago puntual de sus cuotas.
Con el monto de 800 soles, comprará productos de belleza como perfumes, cremas corporales, cremas de manos, talcos, cosméticos y otros accesorios para tener en stock para sus clientes.
texts.en:
Marisol sells beauty products such as colognes, perfumes, clothing and other items.  She does all her work either from home or in the as a street vendor.  She has been in business for six years after learning sales techniques and receiving training.  What she enjoys about her job is the fact that she has time to do all the things she likes while also taking care of her daughter.  Business is doing well and Marisol has enough income to think about future plans.  But what she wants to do for now is to continue expanding and increasing her range of products so she can multiply her profits.

This is her second Kiva loan and and she is happy knowing she will receive financial support because it will generate more security for her to advance in her work.  She is committed to paying back the loan on time.

She will use the 800 PEN loan to buy beauty products such as perfumes, body creams, hand creams, talcum powders, cosmetics and other accessories to have on hand for her customers.

loans.use: To buy beauty products such as creams and cosmetics to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.es: Luisa tiene 31 años de edad, es madre soltera, y vive en su casa propia junta su hijo. Luisa se dedica al servicio de cosmetología. Atiende a diversos clientes que requieren de algún arreglo estético como corte de cabello, tintes, y otros. Además, vende productos de belleza femeninos como tintes, labiales, perfumes y otros. Se inició en esta actividad hace más de 03 años y hasta el momento lo realiza sola. Considera a su negocio bastante rentable por las buenas ganancias que le deja gracias a su fiel clientela. Ahora se siente una empresaria próspera e independiente. Espera continuar su negocio y poco a poco implementar un espacio en su casa para que pueda atender con mayor comodidad. Este es el tercer préstamo con Kiva. Está contenta y agradecida con las personas que hacen posible su crédito que le servirá para continuar con sus planes. Por eso se compromete a ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas como en créditos anteriores. Con el monto de 1500 nuevos soles, comprará artículos que usa en su trabajo de cosmetóloga como tintes capilares, cremas, peines y otros.
texts.en:
Luisa, 31, is a single mother and lives with her son in her own home.  She has a beauty businesas and attends to customers who require some kind of beauty treatment such as hair cuts, color and other services.  She also sells women's products such as hair color, lipstick, perfumes and other items.  She started her business over three years ago and so far works alone.  In her opinion, the business is fairly profitable because of her high earnings thanks to her loyal customers.  Now she feels like a prosperous, independent entrepreneur.

She hopes to continue her business and little by little set up a space at home where she can attend to customers more comfortably.  This is her third Kiva loan and she is grateful to the lenders for helping her continue with her plans.  That is why she is committed to paying back the loan on time as with her previous loans.  She will use the 1,500 PEN to buy articles for her beauty business such as hair color, conditioners, combs and other items.

loans.use: To buy hair color and conditioners for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Lleni

texts.es:
Lleni tiene 28 años, está casada y vive en su casa propia junta su esposo y sus 4 hijos. Lleni se dedica a la venta de productos comestibles, su negocio está ubicado el interior de su propia casa. Se inició en esta actividad hace 5 años. Con mucho esfuerzo pudo establecer su propia tienda en su casa y está más tranquila por el momento. Al principio fue difícil obtener clientes porque ay muchas otras tiendas en el barrio, pero ahora tiene muchos clientes fieles. Le gusta mucho lo que hace ya que le permite poder ver a sus niños en su casa, además le está yendo muy bien ya que genera muchos ingresos para su hogar, tiene muchos planes para su negocio como agrandarlo y así poder vender en mayor cantidad. Es el séptimo préstamo con Kiva, y está muy contenta por el apoyo financiero que está recibiendo y por la confianza que tienen en ella para seguir adelante.
Con el monto de 1800 soles, comprará 3 sacos de arroz, 2 sacos de azúcar, cajas de leche grande, entre otros productos por su tienda.
texts.en:
Lleni, 28, is married and lives with her husband and four children in her own house.  She runs a grocery store which she opened at home five years ago.  With a lot of effort she was able to establish her business and things are running smoothly.  At first it was difficult to attract customers because of the many stores in the neighborhood but now she has a loyal following.

She very much enjoys her work because it gives her time to spend with her children.  It is also a good business that generates a high income for her household.  Lleni has plans to expand her store so she can sell more merchandise.  This is her seventh Kiva loan and she is grateful for the financial support she is receiving and the confidence shown in her.

With the 1,800 PEN she will buy three sacks of rice, two sacks of sugar, cases of milk and other groceries.

loans.use: To buy ingredients such as rice, sugar and mlik to sell at her store.

loans.name: Phoern's Group

texts.en: Coming from a rural village in the Tbaung Khum district of Cambodia, Phoern is aged 35 years and married with four children. She and her husband are hard-working farmers who earn a living through farming rice and cassava. They have been in this business for several years. Phoern’s group is just with VisionFund this cycle. Phoern, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland and spend on labor. She hopes this loan will enable her to increase her business to make more income so as to make a living better.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and seeds for her farmland.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Hellen Isabel

texts.es: Hellen, tiene la edad  de 22 años, está soltera,  vive con su hijo, hermanos y padres, los cuales son mayor prioridad. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de madera y materiales para realizar el acondicionamiento de un cuarto de habitación y pagar mano de obra en los trabajos a realizar, y así poderle ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a su hijo y a su familia. Con esta compra pretende hacer una mejora de buena calidad a su casa y que su familia mejoré su calidad de vida y aprovechar precios bajos en algunos materiales y que son de buena calidad. Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. El no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Hellen, 22, is single and lives with her son, siblings and parents, who are her main priority.  She plans to use the loan to buy wood and materials and hire workers to renovate her home.  She wants to give her son and family a better quality of life and hopes to be able to take advantage of bargain prices on some of the better quality materials.

This is her first loan through FUDECOSUR.  She has never had a state bank loan but FUDECOSUR is giving her better payment terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: To renovate her house.

loans.name: Timani Group

texts.en:
Temani is a group composed of three Lebanese women. They decided to form the group in order to support each other financially. Iman is the leader and featured member of the group. She is a 47-year-old married mother of two children, and she is standing in the center of the picture. She owns a small bakery where she prepares manakish, the traditional Lebanese breakfast served with several different delicious toppings (cheese, thyme etc…). Her husband also owns a small business where he is charge of car painting. Her children are enrolled in a public school because they cannot afford anything more expensive.  She decided to establish this group in order to purchase raw materials such as flour, oil, thyme and cheese to strengthen her business . In addition to that, she might buy furniture to enhance the environment of her household.

As for the other group members, Zeina is the woman wearing red, while Abir is standing on the far right of the picture.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials such as flour, oil, thyme and cheese  to strengthen her business

loans.name: Ngem's Group

texts.en:
A citizen from a rural village located in the Pursat Reap province’s Kror Kor district, Ngem, 43, is married with eight children, two of whom are dependent on her and still in school. For the last 12 years, she has been farming rice to support her family. 

Ngem has been with VisionFund for six cycles, and she has completely paid back her loans, which have enabled her to better her family’s living conditions. Now, she is leading her group to ask for a new loan. As the leader, Sokhom wants to use her portion to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for her farmland. She hopes to make more income from her paddy field business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for her farmland

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To cover the school fees for her daughter.

loans.name: Deme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dème, composé de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 48 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Klakouma, commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioîla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de céréales, tel que le riz, le mil etc.                                                                
Les femmes du groupe sont à leur seizième prêt. 
La cliente Fatoumata, la personne assise à gauche fait le commerce de riz et compte acheter 200 kilos de production locale auprès des producteurs. L vente se fait au comptant et en détail, à une clientèle constituée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour les besoins de la famille et une partie est réinvestie dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The Dème group is made up of married women, who average 48 years of age, with an average of five children each, and who all live in large traditional families in the village of Klakouma, in the municipality of Massigui, in the Dioïla prefecture in the Koulikoro region (the Republic of Mali's second administrative region).

They got to know each other through relatives, neighbors and friends and all trade in cereals, such as rice, millet etc. The women in the group are on their 16th loan.

The customer, Fatoumata, who is sitting on the left of the photo, trades in rice and is planning to buy 200 kilos of local produce from farmers. She sells for cash and on a retail basis to a customer base made up essentially of women.

She is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 20,000FCFA, which will be used for the family's needs; part will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy hulled rice.

loans.name: Hawanatu

texts.en:
This is 42-year-old Hawanatu. She is married and has three children, ages 3, 12 and 17 years. In 1990, Hawanatu established her slippers and clothing business. She inherited this business from her aunt, who brought her up because she never went to school. This business is her only means of livelihood, says Hawanatu. 

Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, Hawanatu earns about SLL 1,200,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan of SLL 5,000,000. Hawanatu requires a loan in order to buy different kinds of clothing and slippers for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately SLL 500,000. Hawanatu is fully supporting her husband for the children’s education. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more plastic slippers and clothing for her business.

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en:
Khalil is 24 years old and single. He lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He has a cafeteria where he sells sandwiches and juices. He likes this business because he thinks it offers good services for his clients. He sold some of his jewelery and land in order to establish his business. 

Recently, Khalil doesn’t have enough money to buy products for his business. Therefore, he has asked for a youth loan in the amount of YER 200,000 to buy products such as sandwiches and juices for his business. He hopes that this will enable him to attract more clients and increase his profits.

loans.use: to buy products such as sandwiches and juices for his business.

loans.name: Sebeke Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe SEBEKE, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 36 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans la ville de Barouéli, préfecture de Ségou, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de tubercules, de savon, d’articles divers et de céréales.                                                                                                                                    
Les femmes du groupe SEBEKE, sont à leur vingtième prêt.                                                                         
La cliente BINTOU assise en première position à partir de la droite, compte acheter de l’habillement chez les grossistes à Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes quotidiennement sur place à Barouéli au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer les contributions des cérémonies sociales et le reste sera  réinvesti dans son activité de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of Sebeke Group average 36 years of age and three children. They are all married and live in extended traditional families in Barouéli, a town in Ségou Prefecture, Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They got to know each other through bonds of kinship, community, and friendship. They sell tubers, soaps, cereals, and various items. The women of Sebeke Group are seeking their twentieth loan.

Bintou (the woman sitting on the right in the photograph) intends to buy clothing from wholesalers in Bamako. She sells daily in Barouéli, for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women.

She intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 75'000 (ca US$ 150) to be used in part to cover her contribution to social ceremonies. The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Fousseyni

texts.fr:
Monsieur Fouseyni est  né vers 1973, il est père de trois enfants et vit dans une famille nucléaire à Konobougou, cercle de Barouéli, Région de Ségou République du Mali. 
Monsieur Fouseyni, exerce le commerce de la pneumatique et accessoires il y’a plus de dix ans. Il s’approvisionne en pneu, chambre à air et les jantes  à Bamako qu’il vend à Konobougou en détail.  Il détient un magasin aux abords du goudron dans la ville de Konobougou. Il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour mieux organiser son activité. Il est à son troisième prêt et les deux précédents furent correctement remboursés. Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour agrandir son activité et subvenir aux dépenses de la famille
texts.en:
Mr. Fouseyni was born circa 1973. He's the father of three children and lives in a nuclear family in Konobougou, Barouéli Cercle, Ségou Region, Republic of Mali.
 
Mr. Fouseyni has been selling tires and accessories for more than ten years. He gets his supplies of tires, inner tubes, and wheel rims in Bamako, and retails them in Konobougou. He owns a shop on the roadside in Konobougou. 

He works with Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to better organize his business. He is seeking his third loan, and the previous two were repaid without problems.

He foresees turning an average monthly profit of XOF 100'000 (ca US$ 200), to be used to expand his business and cover his family's expenses.

loans.use: to buy tires, inner tubes, and wheel rims

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a 46-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has four children. She has been engaged in the food-vending business. She makes and sells snack foods like banana cue (covered with caramelized brown sugar), camote (sweet potato) and ice candy to earn for a living. Her business started five years ago. Her husband work as a security guard. Erlinda requested a loan 0f 5,000 PHP to buy more ingredients like medium ripe banana, sweet potato and sugar. 

In the future, Erlinda would like to expand her food-vending business to provide her family with good food and quality education.

loans.use: to buy meat, seasonings and vegetables.

loans.name: Mary

texts.es:
Mary, de 41 años, está casada con Emilio y tiene 04 hijos con quienes vive en su casa propia.
Mary se dedica a cuidar los niños de las madres solteras de su distrito, se dedica alimentarlos, protegerlos y darles mucho amor, por eso sus amigas y vecinas dejen en plena confianza a su pequeños hijos, a los que recogen después de sus distintas labores. Lleva 5 años en este negocio y aunque su trabajo a veces suele ser un poco pesado, ella sabe que debe dar todo de si para que los niños esten bien cuidados. Este es su tercer crédito con Kiva y se siente agradecida por el apoyo que recibe para seguir adelante, además se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual. Con el monto solicitado de 1300 soles, comprará juguetes para los niños que atiende y cuida en su hogar.
texts.en:
Mary is 41 years old. She is married to Emilio and has 4 children, whom she lives with in her own home. 

Mary takes care of children of single mothers in her district. She feeds them, protects them and gives them a lot of love. That is why her friends and neighbors totally trust her to leave their small children with, and pick them up after their different jobs. She has had this business for 5 years and although her job is little hard sometimes, she knows that she has to give anything so that the children are well cared for. This is her third loan with Kiva and she is grateful for the support she has received to get ahead. She is also committed to making her payments on time. With the amount of 1300 soles, she will buy toys for the children she serves and cares for in her home.

loans.use: to buy toys for children younger than 5.

loans.name: Natik

texts.en:
Natik, 36, is married, living in the village of Kabali with his wife, two children and retired parents. Natik’s children go to the public school. He’s a very hardworking, enthusiastic man who focuses all his efforts into getting ahead.

Natik works very hard on his own greenhouses where he grows cucumbers, tomatoes and various of vegetables during the whole year. His products are very good quality, and he sells his harvests among vegetable retailers. With the received loan, Natik will purchase a cargo van to start a vegetable-selling business. He will transport his harvest to the capital city open market and sell them for a higher price. 

The credit will significantly increase his family's income. It is obvious that the family's financial needs are significant, but Natik will work hard to solve them and give their children a better life.

He wants to thank all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a cargo van for trading.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with six school-going children. She lives at a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a food kiosk business, selling food stuff made from maize flour, maize flour, and cooking fat to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned the high cost of seasonality as her major challenge, and she dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil for sale

loans.name: Fermín

texts.es: El año pasado Fermín renovó parte de su finca de café convencional y la convirtió a café orgánico. Esto gracias a que obtuvo un crédito de Kiva, el cual también le sirvió para comprar fertilizantes y realizar algunas labores en su finca. Para este año Fermín seguirá con su proyecto de renovar otra parte de su finca, pues en unos tres años tiene planeado que toda su producción sea en su totalidad de café orgánico. Para poder llevar a cabo esto él necesita nuevamente de un crédito de Kiva el cual pagará al final de la cosecha.
texts.en: Last year Fermín renewed part of his farm that had conventional coffee and converted it to organic coffee. This was thanks to obtaining a Kiva loan, which he also used to buy fertilizer and do some work on his farm. This year, Fermín will continue with his project of renewing another part of his farm, because he is planning on having his production be totally organic in three years. In order to do this, he needs a Kiva loan again, which he will pay for at the end of the harvest.

loans.use: to re-plant his farm with organic coffee.

loans.name: Ett

texts.en:
Ett is aged 34 and married. She lives in a rural village of the Sa Ang district of Kandal province and she has three children. To make a living, she has been growing beans and cucumbers for 13 years. She earns about 20,000KHR per day and she can manage to save about 8,000KHR each day after her daily expenses.
 
Ett has been with VisionFund for one cycle and she successfully paid back the first loan which has helped her better support her family. Now she is requesting for a loan of 3,500,000KHR to buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland. She hopes to increase her crop yields and earn more income to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for her farmland

loans.name: Heremakono Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Heremakono, composé de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 48 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Klakouma, commune de Massigui, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce de vanne et la vente de haricot préparé.                                                                 
Les femmes du groupe Heremakono sont à leur seizième prêt solidaire. 
La cliente Alimata, debout au milieu fait le commerce de haricot pendant la nuit. Elle compte acheter 1 sac de haricot et des condiments pour la préparation vente  du haricot la nuit, à une clientèle diverse et variée, au comptant et en détail.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour ses besoins de la famille et une partie est réinvestie dans l’activité.
texts.en:
Heremakono Group is made up of married women who average 48 years of age and five children. They all live in extended traditional families in Klakouma, a village in Massigui Commune, Dioïla Prefecture, Koulikoro Region (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They got to know each other through bonds of kinship, community, and friendship. They sell basketry and prepared beans, and are seeking their sixteenth solidarity loan (group loan).

Alimata (the woman standing in the middle) is selling beans during the night. She intends to use one sack of beans and condiments required to prepare beans that she sells at night, retail and for cash, to a very diverse clientele.

She foresees turning an average monthly profit of XOF 10'000 (ca US$ 20) to used in part to provide for herself and her family. The other part will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy beans and condiments

loans.name: Monica

texts.es: Mónica, de 23 años de edad, está casada con Juan y tiene 02 hijos de 05 y 02 años de edad respectivamente con quienes vive en su casa propia. Mónica se dedica a la venta de plátanos. Todos los días instala una mesa al costado de la tienda de su madre, de esa manera oferta sus productos a los clientes de la bodega donde no se vende este producto. En algunas ocasiones diversifica sus ventas con algunas verduras regionales como pepino, ajíes, limones u otros. Tiene más de 03 años realizando éste negocio y hasta el momento se dedica sola a atender a sus clientes de manera amable y cordial. Le gusta su negocio pues le genera un ingreso económico y le permite tener una ocupación y sentirse una persona productiva. Considera a su negocio bastante rentable ya que logra vender todos sus productos, además tiene planes de comprarse un mototaxi y alquilarlo para así generarse más ingresos económicos. Este es su cuarto préstamo con Kiva y se siente agradecida por el apoyo financiero que recibe para seguir adelante, además se compromete a pagar sus cuotas de manera puntual. Con el monto solicitado de 2500 nuevos soles comprará plátanos y algunas verduras al por mayor.
texts.en: Mónica is 23 years old, married to Juan and has two children who are 5 and 2 years old. She lives with her family in her own home. Mónica sells plantains. Everyday she is busy at a table that she sets up to one side of her mother's store and from here she offers her produce to customers. Sometimes, she likes to diversify her product by offering regional vegetables such as cucumber, chili peppers, lemons and others. She has been selling vegetables for 3 years and she always attends to her customers in a cordial and friendly way. She likes her business because she is able to earn some money but also because she is able to have her own profession and feel productive. She considers her business to be very profitable because she typically sells all her produce. She also has plans to buy a mototaxi and to rent it out to others in order to earn even more money. This is her fourth loan with Kiva and she is very thankful for the financial support she has received in order to continue forward in her business. She also promises to repay her loan on a timely basis. With the credit she will purchase more wholesale plantains and some other vegetables.

loans.use: purchase wholesale plantains and vegetables

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: El año pasado Doña Francisca resembró parte de su finca pues ha estado realizando los cambios para que toda su producción sea de café orgánico. Esto fue posible gracias a que obtuvo un crédito por parte de Kiva y para este año ella quiere comprar fertilizante y realizar labores de limpieza en su finca. Si todo sale como planea dentro de 3 años estará produciendo un total de 15 toneladas.
texts.en: Last year Francisca replanted part of her farm as she has been carrying out changes to make her coffee crop totally organic.  This was made possible by a loan obtained through Kiva, and this year she wants to buy fertiliser and clean her farm.  If all goes to plan, she will be producing a total of 15 tonnes within the space of 3 years.

loans.use: to buy fertiliser and to clean her farm.

loans.name: Nissondia Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Nissondia, composé de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 47 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Klakouma, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font la confection et vente de vannes.                                                                 
Les femmes du groupe Nissondia sont à leur seizième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter des vannes.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  
La cliente Yama Yacouba, 1 ère de la gauche vers la droite, compte acheter une grande bande de feuille de bambou pour confectionner  une centaine de vanne. Ces vannes seront vendues  en détail à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour ses besoins de la famille et une partie est réinvestie dans l’activité.
texts.en:
Nissondia Group is made up of married women who average 47 years of age and five children. They all live in extended traditional families in Klakouma, a village in Koulikoro Region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They got to know each other through bonds of kinship, community, and friendship. They make and sell basketry, and are seeking their sixteenth solidarity loan (group loan) in order to buy raw materials.

Yama Yacouba (first woman on the left in the photograph) intends to buy a big length of bamboo leaves to make about one hundred baskets. She will then retail them to a clientele comprising both men and women.

She foresees turning an average monthly profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 80) to be used to provide for her family and, in part, reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy bamboo leaves to wave baskets

loans.name: Lastenia

texts.es: Lastenia tiene 48 años, está casada y vive su propia casa junta su esposo y su hija. Lastenia se dedica a la venta de productos comestibles como arroz, azúcar, pan y otros. Para eso cuenta con una tienda que está instalada en su casa y es 5 años que viene trabajando en su tienda. Realiza esta actividad sola y en ocasiones con el apoyo de su  esposo cuando tiene ratos libres.
